'''Barkin' Bill Smith''' (August 18, 1928 – April 24, 2000)<ref name="Blues">{{cite web|url=http://www.wvbluessociety.org/Mountains%20of%20Blues%20'lectric%20News/lectric%20News/Vol.%201,%20Issue%203%20-%20August%2028,%202008.pdf|title=West Virginia Blues Society : Mountain Blues|publisher=Wvbluessociety.org|accessdate=2014-01-24}}</ref><ref name="Dead"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/barkin-bill-mn0000784196/biography |title=Barkin' Bill | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> Although he was born in [[Cleveland, Mississippi|Cleveland]], [[Mississippi]],<ref name="Blues"/> Smith spent his latter years in [[Chicago]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Smith was raised in Mississippi, but later relocated to [[East St. Louis, Illinois|East St. Louis]], [[Detroit]] and finally Chicago. He obtained his [[stage name]] from [[Homesick James]] in 1958, after the pair had worked together. Smith sang in front of various blues bands around Chicago for many years, having been initially influenced by [[Joe Williams (jazz singer)|Joe Williams]], [[Jimmy Witherspoon]] and [[Brook Benton]].<ref name="AMG"/> He finally made his [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] debut in 1991, providing the [[human voice|vocals]] on [[Dave Specter]]'s first [[album]], ''Bluebird Blues''.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 168 
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>  His connection with [[Delmark Records]] then continued when they issued Smith's own solo debut, ''Gotcha!'', in 1994.<ref name="AMG"/> ''Gotcha!'' featured guitar work by [[Steve Freund]].<ref name="Overview">{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/gotcha%21-mw0000126044 |title=Gotcha! - Barkin' Bill | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

In his latter years declining health restricted his live appearances.<ref name="Center">{{cite web|url=http://www.centerstagechicago.com/music/whoswho/Barkin'BillSmith.html |title=Barkin' Bill Smith |author= |publisher=Centerstagechicago.com |accessdate=August 7, 2010}}</ref>

Smith died in April 2000 in Chicago, from [[pancreatic cancer]], at the age of 71.<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2000.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2000 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

==Solo album discography==
